author: By Ben Shpigel
title: A Plan Just Might Be Coming Together for the Buccaneers
description: The team wanted Tom Brady to smooth out its offense so its defense could shine. In a dominant win over Green Bay, that’s exactly what happened.
content: So maybe — maybe, maybe, maybe — this is how the Tampa Bay Buccaneers’ thrust into N.F.C. contention begins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Fried
title: I Was Reagan’s Solicitor General. Here’s What Biden Should Do With the Court.
description: Joe Biden should be open to enlarging the number of justices. But first, he should see if the conservative majority overplays its hand.
content: Joe Biden got it exactly right in expressing an ambivalent openness to pushing for legislation — entirely constitutional — enlarging the number of Supreme Court justices, if Democrats win the presidency and the Senate in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John M. Barry
title: What Fans of ‘Herd Immunity’ Don’t Tell You
description: A proposal to let people with low risk of infection live without constraint could lead to a million or more preventable deaths.
content: No matter their politics, people nearly always listen to those who say what they want to hear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Migrant Workers Restricted to Farms Under One Grower’s Virus Lockdown
description: The guest workers have been prevented from all but carefully controlled trips to avoid contracting or spreading Covid-19. ‘I never expected to lose my freedom,’ said one.
content: CHERITON, Va. — Each spring, a thousand or more Mexican tomato pickers descend on Virginia’s Eastern Shore to toil in the fields of Lipman Family Farms, enduring long hours stooped over to pluck the plump fruit and then hoisting it on their shoulders onto a waiting truck. An adept worker will fill a 32-pound bucket every two and a half minutes, earning 65 cents for each one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: Fraternity That Reveres Robert E. Lee Faces Revolt Over Racism
description: How a racial awakening unfolded in a white-dominated brotherhood known for its veneration of the Confederate general.
content: Kappa Alpha, one of the nation’s largest and oldest college fraternities, is not unaccustomed to fending off charges of racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Nuwer
title: Slow Lorises Are Adorable but They Bite With Flesh-Rotting Venom
description: Slow lorises are one of the world’s only venomous mammals. Even rarer, they use their venom on one another.
content: With their bright saucer eyes, button noses and plump, fuzzy bodies, slow lorises — a group of small, nocturnal Asian primates — resemble adorable, living stuffed animals. But their innocuous looks belie a startling aggression: They pack vicious bites loaded with flesh-rotting venom. Even more surprising, new research reveals that the most frequent recipients of their toxic bites are other slow lorises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Oil Industry Turns to Mergers and Acquisitions to Survive
description: With the price of a barrel stuck around $40 and no recovery in sight, companies are combining to cut costs and ride out the pandemic.
content: HOUSTON — The once mighty oil and gas industry is flailing, desperately trying to survive a pandemic that has sharply reduced demand for its products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Fauci, Voter Registration, Immigration: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harvey Araton
title: Losing Courtside Camaraderie in the Covid Era
description: With fan attendance most likely limited, if not in doubt, for next season, our former columnist reflects on what could be lost from courtside observers.
content: On that fateful February night in 2017, after Charles Oakley was dragged out of Madison Square Garden and arrested on the accusation of causing a ruckus involving the Knicks’ owner, I made my way down from the press box high atop the court to consult with my source of four decades in the first row behind the Knicks’ bench.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Albertus
title: Will Chile Set an Example for True Democracy?
description: Pinochet’s Constitution needs an overhaul, but the process is not without risks.
content: On Oct. 25, Chileans will vote to reject or approve the start of creating a new constitution. The citizens of more countries should do the same. The country’s current Constitution, written under the authoritarian rule of the dictator Augusto Pinochet, has protected conservative interests and the military and has suppressed political dissent for 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Alan S. Boyd, Nation’s First Transportation Chief, Dies at 98
description: Lyndon B. Johnson chose him to lead a new department integrating vast air, sea and land systems. He also led Amtrak and the Illinois Central Railroad.
content: Alan S. Boyd, the first United States secretary of transportation, who was named by President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1966 to integrate the nation’s sprawling networks of planes, trains, ships and highways into a new superagency, died on Sunday in Seattle. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Wiener
title: What I Learned When QAnon Came for Me
description: I’m a gay, Jewish Democrat — the perfect target for an internet cult obsessed with pinning pedophilia on gays, Jews and Democrats.
content: Before I became the center of a QAnon conspiracy theory, I followed the news about this internet cult with alarm, but also from afar. I saw it as a scary thing happening to people I didn’t know. Then QAnon followers sent me over a thousand death threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Ballet Finds Itself on Higher Ground, Overlooking Lincoln Center
description: Six short works, including three premieres, were unveiled on a rooftop to benefit the new organization Dancers of N.Y.C.B.
content: A dance on a rooftop is a mysterious thing. How is it that a roof is more like water than land? The breeze that comes with elevation, the way the air dances around you as you watch bodies in motion, unlocks something that can’t be replicated on a stage or even, for some strange reason, on grass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Shane Goldmacher and Michael Crowley
title: Trump Team Unveils $55 Million Ad Blitz on a Day of Scattershot Attacks
description: The president and his campaign competed again on Monday, with his slash-and-burn remarks swamping news coverage even as his advisers used conventional levers to try to lift his campaign.
content: President Trump’s re-election campaign on Monday announced a $55 million advertising blitz for the final two weeks of the race in a string of battleground states, as the president spent the day unleashing attacks against Joseph R. Biden Jr., Dr. Anthony S. Fauci and the news media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hahna Yoon
title: A Centuries-Old Korean Style Gets an Update
description: The hanbok, a traditional form of Korean dress, is being embraced by K-pop stars and adapted by innovative designers.
content: When the K-pop band Blackpink released the music video for their song “How You Like That” in June, fans began asking about the group’s outfits, which appeared at once traditional and contemporary. Who was the designer behind Jennie’s cropped pink jacket, they wanted to know, and what inspired the look?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Alan Feuer
title: Justice Dept. Says Trump’s Denial of Rape Accusation Was an Official Act
description: The writer E. Jean Carroll sued the president for defamation after he denied sexually assaulting her in the 1990s. Now the government wants to defend him.
content: The Justice Department said on Monday that President Trump should not be sued personally for having denied a rape allegation because he made the statement while acting in his official capacity as president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Dan Kluger Helps Vegetables Realize Their Full Potential
description: In his new cookbook, “Chasing Flavor,” the chef of Loring Place gives seasonal produce a starring role.
content: What exactly does “Chasing Flavor,” the title of Dan Kluger’s new cookbook, mean? Perhaps that you had better eat your well-seasoned, vibrantly sauced vegetables — and there are plenty of recipes for them in the book. But even if you do, you won’t get dessert; Mr. Kluger, who owns Loring Place in Greenwich Village, doesn’t give any. But he provides ample pleasures, including two versions of his wonderful baked ricotta strewn with vegetables; a rich corn soup; several cured and raw fish recipes; a celery and celery root Caesar salad; and a splendid method for pan-roasting chicken breasts. The book is technique-oriented, and the recipes come with useful tips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Utopia’ Review: Charles L. Mee’s New Play Is a Frothy Escape
description: The playwright whips up a virtual ensemble of eccentrics, but his vision feels out of step with the moment.
content: Quick etymology lesson: The word utopia comes from the Greek. It means “no place.” So maybe it makes sense that Charles L. Mee’s new play “Utopia,” produced by San Francisco’s Cutting Ball Theater and streaming through Nov. 15, feels so untethered. A whimsical ensemble drama, a dance performance and an online gallery show, it is so dissevered from the terrestrial that it melts into pixelated air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Will Dudding
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: China’s economy surges ahead.
content: As most of the world still struggles with the pandemic, China is showing that a fast economic rebound is possible when the coronavirus is brought firmly under control. China’s lead could widen further in the months to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Undoing’ and the Presidential Debate
description: Nicole Kidman plays a successful therapist in a new psychological thriller on HBO, President Trump and Joe Biden face off on Thursday and Halloween classics air on TCM and AMC.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 19-25. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: World Series Preview: A Clash of Coasts and Contrasts
description: Los Angeles vs. Tampa Bay. Big spenders vs. penny-pinchers. Stars vs. relative unknowns. The Dodgers and the Rays both dominated to get to this point, but did so in different ways.
content: ARLINGTON, Texas — The shortest and strangest season in Major League Baseball history will finish with a clash of coasts and contrasts. The Los Angeles Dodgers and the Tampa Bay Rays — big spenders and bargain hunters — will crown one region with an unofficial title no one saw coming: inter-sports champion of the pandemic era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: With Covid-19 under control, China’s economy surges ahead.
description: As most of the world still struggles with the pandemic, China is showing once again that a fast economic rebound is possible when the virus is brought under control.
content: As most of the world still struggles with the pandemic, China is showing once again that a fast economic rebound is possible when the virus is brought under control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Haimerl
title: Mask Mandate? In a Montana Town, It ‘Puts Us at Odds With Customers’
description: In Hamilton, business owners are walking a tightrope between keeping people safe from the coronavirus and not driving them away.
content: HAMILTON, Mont. — Outside River Rising Bakery sits an older gentleman, his face uncovered. He’s here every morning, greeting customers as he drinks his coffee and reads. Inside, people mill about, waiting to order. A group of moms chat at a corner table.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Donald Trump Is Losing His Touch. So Is the TV Producer Who Shaped His Image.
description: Mark Burnett helped turn Donald Trump into a national figure with “The Apprentice.” But since 2016, his impact “has kind of gone bust.”
content: Did you catch Steve Harvey’s “Funderdome” on ABC? How about “The World’s Best” on CBS, “The Contender” on Epix, or “World’s Toughest Race: Eco-Challenge” on Amazon Prime? Or the Christian-themed dramas “A.D. The Bible Continues” on NBC and “Messiah” on Netflix?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Rosenberg
title: Republican Voters Take a Radical Conspiracy Theory Mainstream
description: QAnon, with encouragement from the president himself, has moved from online message boards to political rallies and congressional campaigns.
content: DALTON, Ga. — Sitting in the local Republican office most days is a lifelong conservative named Diane Putnam, who got her first taste of politics when Dwight D. Eisenhower was president and she was a little girl telling people that she liked Ike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: David Letterman Isn’t Here to Cheer You Up This Time
description: The veteran TV host is back with more episodes of his Netflix interview series and a perspective that has been altered by the coronavirus pandemic.
content: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — A few days after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, David Letterman sat behind his desk at CBS’s “Late Show” and shared the story of a rally in Choteau, Mont., to raise money for New York. Getting choked up, he told his viewers, “If that doesn’t tell you everything you need to know about the spirit of the United States, then I can’t help you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: How Failures of the Obama-Era Stimulus Could Guide a Biden Administration
description: One crucial lesson: aim big, because there may be only one chance, and an overheating economy is easier to fix than a halting recovery.
content: The person taking the oath of office on Jan. 20 will face an economic mess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Landslide in Vietnam Kills at Least 20 Military Personnel
description: Search-and-rescue efforts were underway after a landslide in the central province of Quang Tri, resulting in what may be the country’s greatest military loss in peacetime.
content: A landslide in Vietnam on Sunday killed at least 20 military personnel and left two missing, the local news media reported, following weeks of torrential rains and flooding that have devastated parts of the country and killed dozens of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Williams Walsh
title: Marching Orders for the Next Investment Chief of CalPERS: More Private Equity
description: The nation’s biggest public pension fund is consistently short of the billions of dollars it needs to pay all retirees their pensions. It seeks higher returns.
content: Ben Meng got the job of chief investment officer of CalPERS by convincing the trustees of the nation’s largest public pension fund that he could hit their target of a 7 percent annual return on investment by directing more of the fund’s billions into private equity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Evo Morales Is Out. His Socialist Project Lives On.
description: Exit polls in Bolivia’s presidential election show a clear victory for Luis Arce, Evo Morales’s chosen successor, who vowed to carry on his vision. Official results are not in yet.
content: LA PAZ, Bolivia — In a presidential election that was widely viewed as a referendum on the legacy of Evo Morales, Bolivia’s first Indigenous president, voters appear to have spoken clearly: They want his socialist project to go on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Marvar
title: Got Crystals? Gem Mining Could Be Your Full-Time Job
description: Some modern-day prospectors make thousands of dollars selling precious stones they dug up themselves.
content: Moonstones in Montana, amethyst and emeralds in North Carolina, garnet and quartz in upstate New York. At pay-to-dig mines around the United States, visitors can paw through piles of mine tailings to uncover crystals and gemstones on “finders, keepers” terms for as little as $10 a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Improbable, Slightly Surreal Plan to Save Fashion’s Printed Matter
description: The new International Library for Fashion Research in Oslo, the brainchild of a fashion odd couple, has very big ambitions.
content: The three men arrived at the front door of Steven Mark Klein’s sublet on the Lower East Side of Manhattan on June 29 in full personal protective equipment, ready to pack up his piles: the dusty Seussian towers of paper had grown up on every surface of the steel tables and shelves in the small apartment where he has lived for almost 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: 5 Ways Families Can Prepare as Coronavirus Cases Surge
description: As winter approaches, we still need to be vigilant about taking precautions.
content: As if parents didn’t have enough to worry about, here’s a new cause for alarm: Coronavirus cases in the United States are climbing toward a third peak, troubling epidemiologists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Biden focuses on shuttered bars and clubs in a new ad faulting Trump.
description: A new Biden ad focuses on bars and clubs that are struggling for survival in the pandemic.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. is flipping the script on President Trump, who has tried to frame the election as a choice between keeping the economy open or returning to coronavirus lockdowns under Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes, Declan Walsh and Eric Schmitt
title: State Dept. to Remove Sudan From List of Terrorist States
description: The move clears the way for the African nation to seek international assistance and potentially to normalize relations with Israel, which officials said could happen in days.
content: WASHINGTON — The State Department will take Sudan off a list of countries that sponsor terrorism, clearing the way for the East African nation’s fragile government to seek international assistance and, potentially, normalized relations with Israel — a diplomatic goal for President Trump before the election next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Wharton
title: How to Grow (and Eat) a Pawpaw
description: When to plant and when to harvest this native North American fruit.
content: Plant in fall or spring. Kentucky State University’s nursery list is a good place to start your search for young trees, if local plant stores don’t stock them. You can also find plants (and seeds and fruit) through Facebook fan clubs, Craigslist, Nextdoor and Etsy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: As Britain Edges Toward Lockdowns, Long-Held Grievances Flare Up
description: Residents of Manchester and other northern English cities have never much cared for the heavy hand of Westminster. They are not liking it any better in the pandemic.
content: LONDON — Britain’s desperate attempt to curb a second wave of the coronavirus has exposed multiple fractures in its politics and society, but perhaps none as jagged as that between Prime Minister Boris Johnson and the mayor of Greater Manchester, the country’s second-largest urban area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Eat Your Way Around the World
description: Gift boxes from Culinary Backstreets will let you travel to Naples, Athens, Barcelona, Mexico City and even Queens, N.Y., from the comfort of your kitchen.
content: These gift boxes from Culinary Backstreets are designed to create a vicarious trip to a city like Naples or Athens at a time when travel is on hold. The company offers food tours of more than a dozen cities, and has assembled worthwhile assortments of often hard-to-find items that represent five of the destinations: Athens, Barcelona, Naples, Mexico City and Queens, N.Y. From Naples there is colatura condiment, coffee, paccheri pasta and a sauce made with Mount Vesuvius tomatoes, among other items; Athens is represented by honey, olive oil and more; the Barcelona box includes romesco sauce and traditional bodega glasses for wine; and from Queens there are items like Peruvian cilantro paste, Thai pad kapao chile paste and Mexican bowls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Smith
title: Jon Gibson, Minimalist Saxophonist and Composer, Dies at 80
description: Best known for his long association with Philip Glass, Mr. Gibson also worked with Steve Reich, Terry Riley and La Monte Young as well as performing his own music.
content: Jon Gibson, a saxophonist and composer who played a foundational role in Minimalist music, died on Oct. 11 in Springfield, Mass. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Cruise Ship Rescues 24 People From Sinking Boat Off Florida Coast
description: The Carnival Sensation, which was sailing with no guests and a skeleton crew, found the boat in distress 37 miles off the coast of Palm Beach.
content: The Carnival Sensation was sailing in international waters off the Florida coast on Saturday when crew members spotted a crowded 36-foot boat that appeared to be in distress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Election Tech That’s Super Simple
description: The most useful technology doesn’t have to involve flying cars. Sometimes, it’s really easy.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Nagorno-Karabakh, Coronavirus, Thai Protests: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Doctors May Have Found Secretive New Organs in the Center of Your Head
description: They appear to be a fourth pair of large salivary glands, tucked into the space where the nasal cavity meets the throat.
content: After millenniums of careful slicing and dicing, it might seem as though scientists have figured out human anatomy. A few dozen organs, a couple of hundred bones and connective tissue to tie it all together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Rumours’ Returns to the Top 10, Thanks to TikTok
description: The album’s last run in the upper echelons of the Billboard chart was in February 1978.
content: The last time Fleetwood Mac’s classic LP “Rumours” was in the Top 10 of the Billboard album chart, in February 1978, Jimmy Carter was president, disco was king and the prime-time soap opera “Dallas” was still more than a month away from its premiere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Has Trump Drawn the Water for a ‘Republican Blood Bath’?
description: And if he has, what should Biden do with his first term?
content: Bret Stephens: Good morning, Gail. I was reading on social media that Osama bin Laden is alive and well and that he’s living inside Donald Trump’s brain. Care to comment?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Migrant farmworkers under lockdown say restrictions severely limit their freedom.
description: Each spring, a thousand or more Mexican tomato pickers descend on the Eastern Shore of Virginia to toil in the fields of Lipman Family Farms, enduring long hours stooped over to pluck the plump fruit. An adept worker will fill a 32-pound bucket every two and a half minutes, earning 65 cents for each one.
content: Each spring, a thousand or more Mexican tomato pickers descend on the Eastern Shore of Virginia to toil in the fields of Lipman Family Farms, enduring long hours stooped over to pluck the plump fruit. An adept worker will fill a 32-pound bucket every two and a half minutes, earning 65 cents for each one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and J. David Goodman
title: Surprising Results in Initial Virus Testing in N.Y.C. Schools
description: The absence of outbreaks, if it holds, suggests that the city’s efforts to return children to classrooms could serve as an influential model for the nation.
content: [Read more on NYC school closings due to Covid-19]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Just the Thing for Miss Muffet’s 21st Birthday
description: A new clear liquor is made from whey, the milky liquid left over from the cheesemaking process.
content: It doesn’t get much newer or more different than this: Wheyward Spirit, a vodkalike liquor produced from whey, the milky leftover from making cheese and other dairy products. Emily Darchuk, a food scientist who lives in Portland, Ore., was dismayed by how much excess whey was discarded (billions of pounds a year) despite its nutritional value; it’s used to make protein powder, ricotta and some brands of yogurt. She started researching and experimenting to develop a clear spirit, 80 proof, distilled from whey. She uses whey from family farms, and distills the spirit in Sebastopol, Calif., calling the process “farm to flask.” The result is smooth, with a silky texture and a hint of spice that’s elbowed out of the way by its sweet finish, making it alluring on the rocks and adaptable to many white-spirit cocktails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Brush Up Your Pie Skills
description: The cookbook author Kate McDermott teaches a series of pie-making classes online, via the 92nd Street Y.
content: In the run-up to Thanksgiving, learning to make pie is a worthwhile skill. Kate McDermott, who wrote “Art of the Pie” four years ago and who has a new book, “Pie Camp,” will lead a series of three virtual classes in pie-making at the 92nd Street Y. The first one covers making dough. Next, the subject will be chess pie, a simple filling (and if you master chess pie you’re on your way to pecan for Thanksgiving). The final session covers fruit pies, notably pear, with a lattice top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘With Nowhere to Go, Teens Flock to Among Us’
description: In this lesson, students examine how The Times reports on a trend they probably know a great deal about, then make a case for the educational value of playing social video games in school.
content: Featured Article: “With Nowhere to Go, Teens Flock to Among Us” by Taylor Lorenz
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: The Bills Won the Stefon Diggs Trade. Right?
description: Diggs has powered Buffalo’s offense. But Justin Jefferson, selected with a pick acquired in the Diggs trade, has been nearly as good for Minnesota.
content: People do not like ties. They want to win, and they want others to lose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Seven Charged in Flying Squirrel Trafficking Ring, Florida Officials Say
description: The scheme involved thousands of flying squirrels that were captured in less than three years and were exported to Asia, the officials said.
content: Seven people have been charged in a Florida-based international flying squirrel trafficking scheme in which thousands of the creatures were exported to Asia, state conservation officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘They Just Get It’: How Women in M.L.B. Found Support in a Group Text
description: In 2019, Jen Wolf felt a lack of support for women like her trying to find work in professional baseball. The group chat she started has become a rare place for mentoring and understanding.
content: When Alyssa Nakken in July became the first woman in major league history to coach on the field, it was big news in the baseball world. But it was a particularly extraordinary development in one small corner of the industry: a text message group featuring dozens of women working in professional baseball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas St. Fleur
title: Orionids Meteor Shower 2020: Watch It Peak in Night Skies
description: Meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.
content: All year long as Earth revolves around the sun, it passes through streams of cosmic debris. The resulting meteor showers can light up night skies from dusk to dawn, and if you’re lucky you might be able to catch a glimpse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: Recognizing Miscarriage as an Occasion for Grief
description: Many people experiencing miscarriages feel isolated or blame themselves, often because pregnancy loss is still veiled in secrecy.
content: The emotion and attention around the model and cookbook author Chrissy Teigen’s decision to discuss her miscarriage on social media a few weeks ago remind us that this is still a topic that is not easy for many people to talk about. Stories of pregnancy loss, and the grief and complex emotions it leaves behind, bring up new issues of how public — or how private — people want to be, and also challenge the health care system to provide truly helpful responses and support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Romans Want to Get Rid of Wild Boars, but Killing Them? That’s Another Matter
description: The euthanizing of a boar and her six piglets on a playground near the Vatican has aroused fury in Rome, a city that has long complained about the often aggressive animals.
content: Wild boars are a menace in Rome, strewing garbage around the city, blocking traffic and causing numerous car accidents. Residents have been demanding action — but not this.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: Pakistan Rescinds TikTok Ban
description: A decision outlawing the social media app was overturned after 10 days with assurances from the Chinese owners that content would be moderated according to local laws.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Just 10 days after introducing a ban on TikTok, the Pakistani authorities said on Monday that they were reversing the decision after receiving assurance from the Chinese-owned social media platform that it would moderate content according to local laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Wharton
title: The Promise of Pawpaw
description: Issues like climate change, economic inequity and access to food have brought more attention to this creamy fruit and its resilient tree.
content: PHILADELPHIA — The new pawpaw patch at the Woodlands, a sprawling historic property along the Schuylkill, still isn’t much to look at. But just give those trees time, said Alkebu-Lan Marcus, the farmer who tends to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: 2,000-Year-Old Cat Etching Found at Nazca Lines Site in Peru
description: Archaeologists came across the faded feline outline while conducting maintenance work at the UNESCO heritage site.
content: The image, stretching for 40 yards on a hillside in Peru, shows a creature with pointy ears, orb-like eyes and a long striped tail. It appears to be a cat lounging, as cats often do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Damien Cave
title: Chasing Illicit Money, Global Officials Circle a Puerto Rican Firm
description: Tax enforcers from five nations are investigating Euro Pacific Bank, which operates in a U.S. territory criticized in the past for its lax financial regulation.
content: Tax authorities from the United States and four other countries have joined forces to stop shadowy global money networks that use international borders to stymie local investigations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: African-American History Museum Displays Kobe Bryant’s Jersey
description: The jersey, which Mr. Bryant wore during the 2008 N.B.A. finals, will be on view at the National Museum of African American History and Culture starting Wednesday.
content: Shortly before the National Museum of African American History and Culture opened to the public in 2016, Kobe Bryant took a walk through its sports gallery, which chronicles Black athletes’ fight for equality and their cultural contributions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Objects Bring You Comfort?
description: What are the tangible things in your life you value most? What is the story behind one thing you own that means more than its monetary worth?
content: For some people, putting on an old shirt that belonged to a loved one or looking at a special photo is comforting when they feel alone. For others, going to sleep every night with a beloved stuffed animal is a favorite nighttime ritual. What are the things you own that make you feel better during tough times?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: Manly Trump Sinks Waterlogged Liberals in ‘Shipwreck’
description: Anne Washburn’s would-be epic of power and powerlessness, presented as a podcast, may be too close to current events to fulfill its big ambitions.
content: Shakespeare, no dunce, set his history plays among the long-gone and largely forgotten. “Richard II,” for instance, took its first bow two centuries after the actual Richard II took his last. That was long enough to outwit nit-pickers and squeeze poetry from a monster.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: How the W.N.B.A. Became an Avatar of Social Activism
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 19, 2020.
content: “People have power and don’t know it, or if they do know it, they abuse it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Disney Adds Warnings for Racist Stereotypes to Some Older Films
description: “These stereotypes were wrong then and are wrong now,” a 12-second disclaimer on the Disney+ streaming service reads.
content: They are classic animated films like “Dumbo” (1941) and “Peter Pan” (1953), but on Disney’s streaming service they will now get a little help to stand the test of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: India Captures Chinese Soldier Along Disputed Mountain Border
description: But in a sign of a possible thaw, the Indian Army said it would quickly free him.
content: NEW DELHI — The Indian troops fed the captured Chinese soldier a meal. They gave him oxygen and some warm clothes. They treated him respectfully, both sides indicated, and the Indians said that they planned to release him soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: The Bubble Doctor Is In: She Keeps Dance Companies Moving
description: Dr. Wendy Ziecheck has found a new specialty: helping dancers to work together safely. “Testing was the key to making this happen,” she says.
content: Bubble, part of the growing coronavirus vocabulary — the R-factor, zoonotic, sheltering in place — can be used as a noun (“My bubble with 25 other dancers”) or a verb (“Yes, 25! We were bubbling!”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Bruenig
title: A Question of Life and Death Looms for Amy Coney Barrett
description: If confirmed, she may soon have to reconcile her Catholic morality and the law over a death penalty case.
content: After two decades on death row, Ruben Gutierrez’s time nearly came this summer. A little over an hour before he was due to be killed in the execution chamber housed in Texas’ Huntsville Unit, a reprieve arrived from an unlikely source: Justice Samuel Alito.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: After Teacher’s Decapitation, France Unleashes a Broad Crackdown on ‘the Enemy Within’
description: With dozens of raids against Muslim individuals and groups accused of radicalism, the fury of the response had France’s right wing speaking in terms of warfare.
content: PARIS — France on Monday unleashed a broad crackdown on Muslims accused of extremism, carrying out dozens of raids, vowing to shut down aid groups and threatening to expel foreigners as anger swept the country following the decapitation of a middle school teacher for showing caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad in class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airports screened more than one million travelers for the first time since mid-March.
description: More than a million people passed through airport checkpoints on Sunday, the first time the Transportation Security Administration has screened that many people since mid-March.
content: More than a million people passed through airport checkpoints on Sunday, the first time the Transportation Security Administration has screened that many people since mid-March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Michael Crowley
title: Trump calls Fauci ‘a disaster’ and says Americans are tired of virus warnings from ‘these idiots.’
description: President Trump told his campaign staff that Dr. Anthony S. Fauci was “a disaster” and said, “People are tired of hearing Fauci and these idiots.”
content: President Trump attacked Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s leading infectious disease specialist, as “a disaster” on Monday and said, despite experts’ warnings that the nation was headed toward another peak in the coronavirus outbreak, that people were “tired” of hearing about the virus and wanted to be left alone.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Field: A Divided Latino Vote in Arizona
description: Could a strong Hispanic turnout flip the traditionally Republican state for the Democrats?
content: This episode contains strong language.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael P. Jeffries
title: A New Life of Malcolm X Brimming With Detail, Insight and Feeling
description: Thirty years in the making, “The Dead Are Arising,” by Les Payne and Tamara Payne, sharpens our understanding of the Black activist and thinker whose influence continues to reverberate.
content: THE DEAD ARE ARISING The Life of Malcolm X By Les Payne and Tamara Payne
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Europe’s museums are open, but the public isn’t coming.
description: As cultural institutions reopen across the United States, with new coronavirus protocols in place, many have been looking to Europe, where many museums have been open since May, for a preview of how the public might respond to the invitation to return. So far, there’s little reason to be optimistic.
content: As cultural institutions reopen across the United States, with new coronavirus protocols in place, many have been looking to Europe, where many museums have been open since May, for a preview of how the public might respond to the invitation to return. So far, there’s little reason to be optimistic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Azi Paybarah
title: New Yorker Suspends Jeffrey Toobin After Zoom Incident
description: In a statement, the magazine said it was investigating a matter involving the author and CNN legal analyst.
content: [Update: Jeffrey Toobin Is Fired by The New Yorker]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Beds
description: When you’re choosing a bed, think big.
content: When you’re designing a bedroom, there’s no piece of furniture more important than the bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: Covid Hinders Vital Get-Out-the-Vote Events: Black Family Reunions
description: For Black families in particular, reunions allow older generations to teach younger ones about the importance of voting. But in this crucial election year, many of the gatherings have been postponed.
content: Bettie Griggs, a retiree in Los Angeles, was 12 years old and living in Louisiana when her mother received her first voter registration card in the mail. It was 1965.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.1 Million Homes in California
description: A 1925 Craftsman bungalow in Los Angeles, a midcentury home built by Joseph Eichler in Orange and an 1890 Victorian in Napa.
content: Highland Park, in the northeastern part of Los Angeles, is one of the city’s oldest neighborhoods. In the last decade, it has seen an influx of residents drawn to the area for its walkable streets and well-kept Craftsman-style homes. The main thoroughfare is York Boulevard, about half a mile from this house, where businesses include coffee shops, musical instrument stores, traditional Mexican bakeries and quirky mainstays, like Bob Baker Marionette Theater, which has been putting on theater productions for children since the early 1960s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: What to Know About California’s New Rules for Gathering
description: Monday: As we head toward the holiday season, the state has lifted its official ban on private parties. But there are still restrictions.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Unions signal their comfort with reopening Disney parks in California.
description: Marking a potentially significant step toward the reopening of the Disneyland Resort in California, a coalition of unions representing thousands of workers has informed Gov. Gavin Newsom that it is generally satisfied with the health measures laid out by the company for operating safely.
content: Marking a potentially significant step toward the reopening of the Disneyland Resort in California, a coalition of unions representing thousands of workers has informed Gov. Gavin Newsom that it is generally satisfied with the health measures laid out by the company for operating safely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen L. Weintraub
title: Justice Kavanaugh Unlocked Ways to Fight Foreign Interference
description: He made clear the constitutional rights of foreign actors abroad cannot be violated, because they have no constitutional rights.
content: Among many other recent developments not likely on anyone’s 2020 bingo card, a Supreme Court decision about foreign aid and legalized prostitution has shattered perceived constraints on the authority of the United States to robustly defend its elections against foreign interference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: Ancient Philosophy, Meet Modern Pandemic
description: Students at Wesleyan meet mostly in person to discuss virtues and ideals in a complex  modern moment.
content: MIDDLETOWN, Conn. — At Wesleyan University,  the semester looks relatively normal, at least by pandemic standards. Some classes meet in person, and many students live on campus. So far, with extensive testing, cases have remained low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: It’s a Party at Gatsby’s Mansion. No Dancing, Please.
description: An immersive theater show of “The Great Gatsby” has returned in London. Can it keep the novel’s spirit alive while obeying the coronavirus rules?
content: LONDON — One afternoon in September, nine cast members of “The Great Gatsby,” an immersive theater show staged like a party at Jay Gatsby’s mansion, were sweatily dancing the Charleston in a London venue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom
title: ‘Vile, Racist Postings’ by N.Y. Court Officers Included Obama in a Noose
description: A new report found pervasive examples of racial bias — some explicit, some subtle — in New York State’s court system.
content: One white court officer in Brooklyn posted an illustration of President Barack Obama with a noose around his neck on social media. Another white officer referred to a Black court officer as “one of the good monkeys.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and Reid J. Epstein
title: How Prepared Are These 7 Battlegrounds for the Election? A Readiness Report
description: Short on money and under enormous pressure, many swing states are still trying to shore up a democratic process challenged daily by court cases, new laws and surges in the coronavirus.
content: In Georgia, the state’s voting machines have malfunctioned in three consecutive elections this year alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: With Covid-19 Under Control, China’s Economy Surges Ahead
description: Exports jumped and local governments engaged in a binge of debt-fueled construction projects. Even consumer spending is finally recovering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Become a Better Listener. Your Family Will Thank You.
description: Effective communication skills are more important than ever in our close-quarters existence.
content: On a recent morning, my family was assembled in our customary positions at the kitchen table: my husband, Tom, and I hunched over our computers, while our daughter, wearing headphones, did math problems for remote learning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Andrew Knoll
title: Hockey Broadcaster Mike ‘Doc’ Emrick Retires
description: Emrick, NBC’s lead play-by-play voice known for his myriad ways to describe puck movement, had called N.H.L. games for 40 seasons.
content: When the N.H.L. begins its next season, absent for the first time in four decades will be the man perhaps more associated with the league than any player, coach or official: the broadcaster Mike Emrick — known universally by his nickname, Doc.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: I Am Watching My Planet, My Home, Die
description: Our world cannot survive four more years of the Trump administration’s environmental policy.
content: NASHVILLE — I was writing a love letter to autumn and its perfect miracle of timing — the way berries ripen just as songbirds migrate through berry-filled forests — when the songbirds suddenly began to die. With no warning at all, thousands and thousands of birds, possibly millions of birds, were simply falling out of the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: The HORAE, or “Hours,” were the goddesses of the seasons in Greek mythology. They were also considered to be the goddesses of order and justice, as well as the wardens at the gates of Mount Olympus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: High-Level U.S. Mission to Syria Sought Release of American Prisoners
description: Though the two countries barely talk, American officials met in Damascus with a Syrian intelligence chief to discuss two U.S. citizens held in Syria, Austin Tice and Majd Kamalmaz.
content: High-level United States officials traveled recently to Syria for rare talks with the Assad government in an attempt to secure the release of American citizens held prisoner there, a high priority for the Trump administration, but there has been little apparent progress so far, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Fried Chicken You Need Right Now
description: Make Nicole Taylor’s recipe with spicy scallion cornmeal waffles.
content: Good morning. Robert Farrar Capon was a theologian, author and cook, probably best known for his book, “The Supper of the Lamb: A Culinary Reflection.” He died in 2013, at 87. His recipe for sour cream coffee cake lives on at NYT Cooking, though, where it has more than 2,700 five-star ratings. (Less well-known, but perhaps equally awesome, is his recipe for old man’s hash, essentially an onion, egg and anchovy salad, served warm.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Fargo’ Season 4, Episode 5 Recap: Just Boys
description: The Cannons’ strategy so far has been mostly to stand back and allow the Faddas to devour themselves. They weren’t counting on so much collateral damage.
content: “This country loves a man who takes what he wants. Unless that man looks like you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allie Volpe
title: How to Get Your Friends to Stop Treating You Like a Therapist
description: Maintaining our own emotional equilibrium is essential if we’re to be fully present for our companions.
content: The pandemic has left no one untouched, even the most secure among us. The stress of the combined health, economic and racial inequality crises has illuminated and intensified even our seemingly insignificant woes and worries. We’re collectively experiencing a monumental life shift and actively leaning on our inner circle for support as a result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Behind in Polls, Republicans See a Silver Lining in Voter Registrations
description: Democrats lead in overall numbers, as well as early voting, but voter registration gains in three critical states have given Republicans a cause for hope.
content: With President Trump trailing in public polls in nearly every major battleground state, Republicans are pointing to what they see as more promising data: Updated voter registration tallies show that Republicans have narrowed the gap with Democrats in three critical states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Precaution exhaustion could create dire conditions in the fall.
content: Coronavirus cases in the United States are surging toward their third peak in eight months. More than 70,000 new infections were recorded on Friday, the most in a single day since July, and the country recently surpassed eight million total cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why Biden Will Need to Spend Big
description: The economic case for deficit spending is overwhelming.
content: What should Joe Biden’s economic policy be if he wins (and Democrats take the Senate, so that he can actually pass legislation)? I’m pretty sure I know what his economists think he should do, but I’m not equally sure that everyone on his political team fully gets it, and I’m worried that the news media will experience sticker shock — that is, they may not be ready for the price tag on what he should and probably will propose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian Friedman
title: CVS Health will hire 15,000 more workers ahead of flu season.
description: CVS Health announced on Monday that it planned to hire 15,000 workers to prepare for expected increases in coronavirus and flu cases in the United States during the fall and winter months.
content: CVS Health announced on Monday that it planned to hire 15,000 workers to prepare for expected increases in coronavirus and flu cases in the United States during the fall and winter months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Festival Cancels Abu Dhabi Event After Allegations of Sexual Assault
description: An employee of the Hay Festival in Abu Dhabi said she was accosted by the tolerance minister of the U.A.E. earlier this year.
content: LONDON — The Hay Festival, an annual staple of Britain’s literary calendar, announced on Monday that an offshoot event to promote freedom of speech and women’s empowerment would no longer be held in Abu Dhabi after one of its employees accused the United Arab Emirates’ minister of tolerance of sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: A Viral Theory Cited by Health Officials Draws Fire From Scientists
description: A manifesto urging reliance on “herd immunity” without lockdowns was warmly received by administration officials. But the strategy cannot stem the pandemic, many experts say.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic erupted this spring, two Stanford University professors — Dr. Jay Bhattacharya and Dr. Scott W. Atlas — bonded over a shared concern that lockdowns were creating economic and societal devastation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: ‘If There Were No Hashish Here, You Wouldn’t See a Single House’
description: A village in Lebanon, where cannabis grows everywhere, has long counted on hashish for income. But the country’s economic crisis has farmers reconsidering the crop.
content: YAMOUNEH, Lebanon — In a Lebanese farming village of rocky soil and stone villas, cannabis grows everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Hiker Is Found in Zion National Park After Nearly Two Weeks Missing
description: Holly Suzanne Courtier, 38, went missing on Oct. 6 after getting off a shuttle bus at the park in Utah. She was found safely on Sunday, the authorities said.
content: Shortly after Holly Suzanne Courtier set out on a hike in Utah’s Zion National Park nearly two weeks ago, she injured her head on a tree with a blow so disorienting that she could not seek help or stray far. But she survived by staying near water until Sunday, when help found her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Think You Have ‘Normal’ Blood Pressure? Think Again
description: Even levels of blood pressure that are generally considered “normal” may be high enough to foster the development of heart disease, new research shows.
content: So you think your blood pressure is normal? Think again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Clark Middleton, Actor With a Cause, Is Dead at 63
description: Known for his role on “The Blacklist,” he strove to convey the message that his juvenile rheumatoid arthritis was not a limitation.
content: Clark Middleton, a versatile film and television actor who delivered striking performances in supporting roles and whose struggles with rheumatoid arthritis as a child gave him a cause to champion and grist for an autobiographical one-man Off Broadway play, died on Oct. 4 in Los Angeles. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Richard Avedon, a Photographer Who Wanted to Outrun the Glitz Factor
description: Philip Gefter’s new biography, “What Becomes a Legend Most,” argues for Avedon’s place as one of the 20th century’s most consequential artists.
content: The drama of the approaching photo insert nags at the reader of biographies. Do you skip ahead and devour the eye candy? Or do you hold off, slogging toward the photographs as if they were a small, warm inn at the midpoint of a long, pebbly hike?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Cuomo’s Virus Crackdown Angers Catholics, Who Say They’re Singled Out
description: Church leaders, who have clashed with the governor before, said that Catholics have followed mask and social-distancing rules.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is a conflicted Catholic, a former altar boy who nonetheless describes himself as someone who has had problems with the Roman Catholic Church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: New Musical by Weinstein Accuser Set for Screening
description: “The Right Girl,” about a film executive who confronts sexual exploitation, was aimed for a live production. Instead, it was recorded by actors at home.
content: A new musical co-written by a lead plaintiff in a lawsuit against the former Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein will be screened for a live audience at Barrington Stage Company next month, with a cast and creative team that includes notable names like Susan Stroman, Diane Warren and Tony Yazbeck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters and Kathleen Gray
title: Are Michigan Democrats in Trouble in Their Senate Race?
description: In a race in which neither candidate seems to want voters to know whether they are the Republican or the Democrat, polls show a tighter contest than liberals had expected.
content: One candidate slapped on a helmet, a black leather jacket and rode his Harley Davidson across Michigan. His ads highlight his toughness on China and his support for banning Chinese travelers from entering the United States early in the coronavirus outbreak, a policy of President Trump’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Cooper
title: Trump campaigns in Arizona, which was hit hard by the virus.
description: President Trump traveled to Arizona on Monday for rallies in Prescott and Tucson. Here’s a snapshot of how the state has been doing on two of the biggest issues of the day: the coronavirus and the economy.
content: President Trump traveled to Arizona on Monday for rallies in Prescott and Tucson. Here’s a snapshot of how the state has been doing on two of the biggest issues of the day: the coronavirus and the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: excoriate
description: This word has appeared in 14 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Review 2 of Trump’s Major Immigration Policies
description: The court adds to a docket of cases that will test the president’s agenda.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to review two major Trump administration immigration initiatives, adding them to a docket now crowded with cases that will test President Trump’s agenda and policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Nicole Brown
title: Black family reunions are often used to pass down political knowledge. Not in 2020.
description: For Black families in particular, reunions allow older generations to teach younger ones about the importance of voting. But in this crucial election year, many of the gatherings have been postponed.
content: Bettie Griggs, a retiree in Los Angeles, was 12 years old and living in Louisiana when her mother received her first voter registration card in the mail. It was 1965.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Michael Gold
title: Virus Cases Spike in New Jersey, Threatening ‘Lurch Backward’
description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy said that residents should refrain from all but necessary out-of-state travel.
content: Coronavirus cases in New Jersey, an early epicenter of the pandemic, are on the rise again, doubling over the last month to an average of more than 900 new positive tests a day, a worrisome reversal of fortune for a state that had driven transmission rates to some of the nation’s lowest levels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Running the Numbers on Biden’s Tax Policy
description: Will it help or hurt the economy?
content: This Nov. 17 and 18, DealBook opens its doors to our first Online Summit. Join us as we welcome the most consequential newsmakers in business, policy and culture to explore the pivotal questions of the moment — and the future. Watch from anywhere in the world, free of charge. Register now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: The Unintended Racial Horror of ‘Lovecraft Country’
description: The HBO series, which just wrapped up its first season, aimed to upend stereotypes and create a heroic Black story set in Jim Crow America. But it delivered a muddled narrative with sloppy execution.
content: This essay includes spoilers for the first season of “Lovecraft Country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Murderer Who Wielded Narwhal Tusk to Stop Terrorist Gets Royal Pardon
description: Queen Elizabeth II approved a rare form of clemency for an inmate who used a whale tusk to help end a deadly terrorist attack near London Bridge last year.
content: LONDON — Queen Elizabeth II has approved a rare royal pardon for an inmate convicted of murder who used a narwhal tusk to help stop a terrorist attack in which two people were killed before the assailant was killed by the police on London Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Trump is racing from rally to rally. But is it helping him?
description: President Trump is racing from rally to rally, hitting Arizona on Monday. But is it actually helping him?
content: There are 15 days left until Election Day. Tens of millions of Americans have already voted. Joseph R. Biden Jr. is leading in the polls, and President Trump’s last chance to turn things around might be the second — and last — presidential debate on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Corporate Court
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Amy Coney Barrett didn’t duck every substantive question that senators asked at her confirmation hearing last week. When an answer seemed obvious enough to her, she gave it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Coronavirus Relief Deal Remains Elusive
description: Voters want stimulus aid, but it may not arrive: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Pelosi pushes (yet again) for a deal, while Biden’s team issues a warning: It ain’t over till it’s over. It’s Monday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Guyatt
title: 1619, Revisited
description: The loudest criticism of the Times project has been neither productive nor scholarly.
content: More than a year after its appearance in The New York Times Magazine, the 1619 Project continues to drive its critics to distraction. Last month, President Trump convened a “White House Conference on American History” to defend the “magnificent truth about our country” from the “toxic propaganda” of the project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Dodgers Rally to Win N.L.C.S. and Reach 3rd World Series in 4 Years
description: Los Angeles, once down by three games to one in the series, fell behind in Game 7 but came back to earn a return trip to the World Series.
content: Cody Bellinger dropped his bat by his feet, stared up into the sky and began a slow, purposeful strut down the first base line, admiring the towering home run that he had just hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: After big jobs at ABC and Netflix, the executive Channing Dungey takes charge of Warner Bros.
description: Under her leadership, Warner Bros. is expected to be a big supplier for Warner Media’s newish streaming app, HBO Max.
content: Hollywood’s revolving door keeps spinning for top-level executives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Europe’s Museums Are Open, but the Public Isn’t Coming
description: Attendance at some major institutions is a third of what it was last year. Their ability to cope depends almost entirely on how they are funded.
content: AMSTERDAM — Visitors to the Rijksmuseum’s vast, vaulted galleries of Dutch old master paintings can feel as though they’ve got the whole place to themselves these days. Before the pandemic, around 10,000 people used to crowd in each day. Now, it’s about 800.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 19, 2020
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 19, 2020.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 19, 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Maggie Haberman and Noah Weiland
title: Trump Calls Fauci ‘a Disaster’ and Shrugs Off Virus as Infections Soar
description: With two weeks remaining in his re-election campaign, President Trump made the coronavirus his message and Dr. Anthony S. Fauci his foil, dismissing scientific advisers as “these idiots.”
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump attacked Dr. Anthony S. Fauci as “a disaster” on Monday and said, despite signs that the nation was headed toward another coronavirus peak, that people were “tired” of hearing about the virus from “these idiots” in the government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Latest Clash Between China and Taiwan: A Fistfight in Fiji
description: Two mainland diplomats attended an event, uninvited, and took offense at symbols of Taiwan — including a flag on a cake. A scuffle ensued.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — It was supposed to be a quiet diplomatic event at a stylish beachside hotel in Fiji.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: These Teams Would Like Another Shot at Their 2-Point Conversions
description: Washington, Houston and Philadelphia all had their games decided by a lack of execution on conversions late in their games.
content: Touchdowns win football games. Turnovers win football games. Dominating the line of scrimmage wins football games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher R. Weingarten
title: 2020 Is Chaotic. Clipping’s New Horror-Rap Album Captures It.
description: The trio featuring Daveed Diggs, William Hutson and Jonathan Snipes returns with another blast of political music that crosses genres and boundaries.
content: LOS ANGELES — On a sunny October afternoon, the producer Jonathan Snipes heard the distant bloop of a postal scanner and bounded to grab the day’s mail: a box of eight blank cassettes for his Tascam Portastudio along with the comically complicated score to “The People United Will Never Be Defeated!,” from the American composer Frederic Rzewski. The adventurous contemporary-classical ensemble Alarm Will Sound had asked his noise-flecked rap group, Clipping, to submit an interpretation of the politically charged 1975 piano piece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Trump Official’s Tweet, and Its Removal, Set Off Flurry of Anti-Mask Posts
description: The tweet, from Dr. Scott Atlas, one of the president’s top science advisers, was debunked by many experts and deleted by Twitter.
content: For months, public health experts — backed by guidelines from the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention — have stood firm on one resounding refrain: Against the coronavirus, masks work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Miller
title: A 30-Mile Rafting Trip Through Alaska’s Tongass National Forest
description: The Honker Divide Canoe Route draws intrepid travelers through the world’s largest intact temperate rainforest. But the lifting of logging restrictions may indelibly alter its character.
content: At the onset of the coronavirus pandemic, with travel restrictions in place worldwide, we launched a new series — The World Through a Lens — in which photojournalists help transport you, virtually, to some of our planet’s most beautiful and intriguing places. This week, Christopher Miller shares a collection of images from Southeast Alaska.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Qaeda Financier Who Trades in Gems
description: The action shows that the U.S. government remains concerned about how extremist groups like Al Qaeda and the Islamic State continue to creatively raise and distribute money around the world.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Monday imposed sanctions on an Australian-based businessman and his gemstone company for helping Al Qaeda move money across the globe to sustain its operations.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Election Isn’t Doomed … Yet
description: Inside the intricate legal battle to make sure every vote counts in 2020.
content: In part two of Sway’s two-part election integrity series, Kara Swisher speaks to Trevor Potter, a former chairman of the Federal Election Commission and an expert on the dark money and opaque laws that define modern American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Why Things Are Different This Time
description: “But 2016 …” isn’t really a relevant argument in the 2020 race.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: 10,000 Guests at a Hasidic Wedding in Brooklyn? N.Y. Says No.
description: The governor warned that the gathering could be a superspreader event; a synagogue representative accused  officials of “unwarranted attacks.”
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: U.S. to Sign Limited Trade Deal With Brazil
description: The new pact is expected to ease trade barriers, strengthen regulation and crack down on corruption.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States and Brazil have reached an agreement on a limited trade deal that will facilitate commerce between the countries, strengthen regulatory practices and crack down on corruption, officials from the two countries announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: An Earthquake, an Orphanage, and New Beginnings for Haitian Children in America
description: After the 2010 earthquake in Haiti, 19 children from one orphanage were flown to the U.S. to be adopted by American families. One would later meet President Trump.
content: When a devastating earthquake hit Haiti in 2010, a teenager named John Peter was playing basketball in the yard outside the small orphanage where he lived. He felt the earth bounce below him. He heard screams and watched a mushroom cloud of dust rising over the walls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson, Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
title: U.S. Diplomats and Spies Battle Trump Administration Over Suspected Attacks
description: American officials in China, Cuba and Russia say U.S. agencies are concealing the true extent of the episodes, leaving colleagues vulnerable to hostile actions abroad.
content: WASHINGTON — The strange sound came at night: a crack like a marble striking the floor of the apartment above them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Nicole Perlroth
title: U.S. Charges Russian Intelligence Officers in Major Cyberattacks
description: Prosecutors said the suspects hacked elections in France, the electricity grid in Ukraine and the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea.
content: The Justice Department on Monday unsealed charges accusing six Russian military intelligence officers of an aggressive worldwide hacking campaign that caused mass disruption and cost billions of dollars by attacking targets like a French presidential election, the electricity grid in Ukraine and the opening ceremony of the 2018 Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Azerbaijan?
description: Can you find Azerbaijan on a map? What else do you know about this nation with about 10 million people?
content: Can you find Azerbaijan on a map? What else do you know about this nation with about 10 million people?

title: Dawoud Bey, Chronicler of Black American Life
description: The photographer takes pictures of everyday subjects and scenes that at once distill this country’s troubled past and provide a glimpse of a better future.

title: The Greats
description: In our 2020 Greats issue, out Oct. 25, T celebrates five talents who, in mastering their crafts, have changed their fields — and the culture at large.

author: By Megan O'Grady
title: Barbara Kruger Offers a Dark Mirror for Our Meme-Driven Age
description: For nearly five decades, the artist has blurred the lines between political slogans, poetry and the language of advertising, establishing herself as a serious architect of protest and provocation.
content: For nearly five decades, the artist has blurred the lines between political slogans, poetry and the language of advertising, establishing herself as a serious architect of protest and provocation.

title: FKA Twigs Has Reached New Heights
description: Known for her haunting blend of R&B and art-pop, the singer is already a singular presence, but remains unwavering in her pursuit of technical virtuosity.
content: Known for her haunting blend of R&B and art-pop, the singer is already a singular presence, but remains unwavering in her pursuit of technical virtuosity.

author: By
title: Angela Davis Still Believes America Can Change
description: Since the 1970s, the academic and activist has been an icon of feminism and Black liberation. Today, as the battle for equality wages on, the ideas for which she’s long advocated have finally entered mainstream thought.
content: Since the 1970s, the academic and activist has been an icon of feminism and Black liberation. Today, as the battle for equality wages on, the ideas for which she’s long advocated have finally entered mainstream thought.

description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced on Monday that the state will have its own, independent panel of experts review any federally-approved coronavirus vaccines before they are administered to residents.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced on Monday that the state will have its own, independent panel of experts review any federally-approved coronavirus vaccines before they are administered to residents.
